newsitem.title: USA: Netscape in deal with four search firms.
newsitem.headline: Netscape in deal with four search firms.

text.p: Netscape Communications Corp. said on Tuesday it has struck a fresh deal with the four public internet search companies, and will also announce a separate deal with Yahoo! on Wednesday.
Under the multi-company deal, Netscape has agreed to recognize Excite Inc., Infoseek Corp., Lycos Inc. and Yahoo! Inc as Premier Providers for its new Netscape Search program to start on May 1.

The program would replace one in which the four companies and McKinley Group, which Excite acquired last summer, had each paid roughly $5 million to Netscape for a place on the "search" button on the Netscape home page.

Netscape's home page remains the most heavily-accessed site on the World Wide Web, according to surveys of Internet traffic, in part because its Navigator browser is programmed to start out at the Netscape site.
No information was immediately available about the financial terms of the latest "search" button contract.

Netscape said the four premier providers would be featured on tabs, with rotating prominence between them. It said a fifth tab could be customized by users from a list of Marquee Providers, including Excite's Webcrawler, which it procured from America Online.
The new Search page would also enable users to select one provider to appear as their favorite, enjoying the prominent position whenever Netscape Search is accessed.

As part of the deal, the search providers would continue to be Netscape Flagship partners, displaying a Netscape Now button prominently on their own services and using Netscape client and server software for their sites.
A "button" on a Web page is a graphic image which a user may point at using a computer mouse or other pointing device, and move to another site by clicking on the image.

Netscape and Yahoo! said they would outline terms of a second, essentially unrelated deal on Wednesday morning in a teleconference call. No further details were immediately available, although a Yahoo! spokeswoman said a news release will be issued ahead of Wednesday's market open.
The Netscape-Yahoo! deal would be financially material to Yahoo!, according to the company's spokeswoman.

The C/Net online news service reported late on Tuesday that the latter agreement would be a multimillion dollar contract for Yahoo! to manage Netscape's "destinations" pages on its site. These highlight leading-edge sites.
Both companies declined to provide details.

Search company executives have said Netscape was holding a hotly-contested bidding contest for a company to run its destinations site, which would relieve Netscape from day-to-day operational support responsibilities while likely still providing a significant revenue stream.
